Post.title: Pedestrian Behavior Understanding and Prediction with Deep Neural Networks

# [Pedestrian Behavior Understanding and Prediction with Deep Neural Networks](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-46448-0_16)
1. ECCV2016(Shuai Yi)

2. (encoding scheme)CNN

3. 

    > 1. (deep-CNN)(Long-term pedestrian behaviors)CNN

    > 2. (pedestrian behavior encoding scheme), (sparse displacement volumes)
 
4.

: 

    >(a ) (displacement volume) b Behavior CNN displacement volume

* 
![](Pedestrian-Behavior-Understanding-and-Prediction-with-Deep-Neural-Networks/15197894945788.jpg)


    >  $p_1,p_2,...,p_N$$N$, $t_1,t_2,...,t_m$$m$ $t_m$$t_m$ $p_i(i\in[1,N])$ $l_i^m=[x^m_i/X, y^m_i/Y]$$x_i^m\in[1,X]$, $y_i^m\in[1,Y]$ $[X,Y]$ (spatial size)
  
    >  $2M$ $d_i=[l_i^M-l^1_i ,l^M_i-   l_i^2,...,l_i^M-l_i^{M-1},l_i^M-l_i^M]$ $M$ $p_i$ $d_i \in (-1,1)$.
    
    > $d_i$tensor $D\in R^{X\times Y\times 2M}$ $p_i$ $(x_i^M, y_i^M)$ $D(x_i^M,y_i^M,:) = d_i$() $d_i+\textbf{1}^T$ $D(x_i^M, y_i^M,:)=d_i+ \textbf{1}^T$$2M$ $\in(0,2)$,  1 $D$  0
    
* CNN 
![](Pedestrian-Behavior-Understanding-and-Prediction-with-Deep-Neural-Networks/15197998463524.jpg)

    >1. CNN $D\in R^{X\times Y \times 2M}$ $D^* \in R^{X\times Y \times 2M^*}$.

    >2.  $X\times Y \times 64$(feather map zero pad )

    >3. max-pool (stride 2)$X/2 \times Y/2 \times 64$

    >4. (location bias map)$X/2 \times Y/2$ channel-wisely (64channel) pool feather map (bias)  location bias map 

    >5. $D^*$.

*

# [Understanding Pedestrian Behaviors from Stationary Crowd Groups](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2015/papers/Yi_Understanding_Pedestrian_Behaviors_2015_CVPR_paper.pdf)
1. CVPR2015(  :Shuai Yi)

2. (pedestrian behavior)
3. 

    > (stationary crowd groups)(moving crowds)(, )
    ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15198897069641.jpg)

(spatial distribution)(dynamic variations of trafc patterns)

* Pedestrian Behavior Modeling
    
    > (general scene energy map), travel difficulty
    
* (General energy map modeling)

    > 1.  $f_{SL}$2.$f_{MP}$; 3.  $f_{SG}$
    > ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15198918330798.jpg)
$\theta_1,\theta_2,\theta_3,\theta_4$

    #####1.
    >  ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15198919545235.jpg) 
    > 
$SL$$d_1(x,SL)=min_{y\in{SL}}\parallel x-y \parallel_2^2$ $x$$x$ $f_{SL}$

    #####2.
    > ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15198927017157.jpg)

$MP_i$ $i$$x_t^{MP_i}$$MP_i$$t$$x_{t+1}^{MP_i}$$t+1$$d_2(x,MP_i)=(\parallel x-x^{MP_i}_t\parallel +\parallel x-x^{MP_i}_{t+1} \parallel )^2 - (\parallel x_t^{MP_i} - x_{t+1}^{MP_i}\parallel)^2$,$x$$MP_i$(social-force model)

    #####3.
    ()
    ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15199214092427.jpg)
$SG_i$$i$$d_3(x,SG_i)=min_{y\in{SG_i}}\parallel x-y \parallel^2_2$$x$$SG_i$$d_4(SG_i)$ $SG_i$ ($d_4$)$x\in SG_i$$d_3(x,SG_i)=0$.

* (Personalized energy map modeling)
 $P$.
 ![](Understanding-Pedestrian-Behaviors-CVPR2015/15199222658062.jpg)
$P$$\theta_1,\theta_2,\theta_3$$P$(walking aggressively and cares less about obstacles.)

*

*

K$x_1,x_2,...,x_k$$X=\{x_1,x_2,...,x_k\}$

Post.title: You'll never walk alone
Post._content:
# [You'll Never Walk Alone: Modeling Social Behavior for Multi-target Tracking](http://vision.cse.psu.edu/courses/Tracking/vlpr12/PellegriniNeverWalkAlone.pdf)
*  ICCV2009558

* LTA(Linear Trajectory Avoidance)(The model is designed for walking people with short-term prediction in mind).

##Modeling Social Behavior:

1. $s_i = (p_i^t, v_i^t)$ $i$$p_i^t$$v_i^t$$i$()====
2. $s_i$$\tilde{v}_i$$s_j$$t$$d_{ij}^2(t)$ $$d_{ij}^2(t,\tilde{v_i})=\|p_i+t\tilde{v_i}-p_j-tv_j\|$$
$d_{ij}$$\tilde{v_i}$$s_i$
3.  $k_{ij}^t = p_i^t-p_j^t$, $q_{ij}^t =\tilde{v}_i-v_j^t$, $$d_{ij}^2(t,\tilde{v_i})=\|k+  tq\|^2$$
4. $s_i$$s_j$$s_i$${d_{ij}^*}^2$(comfortable distance)$t^*$$s_i$$s_j$:$$t^*= \underset{t>0}{\arg\min}\ d_{ij}^2(t,\tilde{v}_i)$$
5. $d_{ij}^2(t,\tilde{v_i})$$t$$t$,$0$$$\frac{\partial{d_{ij}^2(t,\tilde{v}_i)}}{\partial{t}}=2(k+ {tq})q^{\top}=0 \rightarrow t^*=-\frac{k \cdot {q}}{\|q\|^2}$$
6. $t^*$: $${d_{ij}^*}^2(\tilde{v_i})=\|k-\frac{k\cdot{q}}{\|q\|^2}q^{\top}\|^2$$

    (${d_{ij}^*}^2(\tilde{v_i})$ is the expected minimum distance between pedestrian $i$ and $j$ under a constant-velocity assumption)$s_i$$s_j$${d_{ij}^*}^2(\tilde{v_i})$$s_i$$\tilde{v_i}$
7. $s_i$$s_j$$E_{ij}$$s_i$$s_j$${d_{ij}^*}^2$$$E_{ij}(\tilde{v}_i)=e^{-\frac{{d_{ij}^*}^2(\tilde{v_i})}{2\sigma_d^2}}$$
$\sigma_d$()$E_{ij}$;${d_{ij}^*}^2$$E_{ij}$
8. $s_i$$s_r(r\neq i)$,$s_i$$\phi$$w_r(i)$: $$w_r(i)=w_r^d(i)w_r^\phi(i)$$ $$w_r^d(i)=e^{-\frac{\|k_{ir}\|^2}{2\sigma_w ^2}}$$ $$w_r^{\phi}=((1+cos(\phi))/2)^{\beta}$$ $\sigma_w$$\beta$ 
9. $s_i$(overall interaction energy): $$I_i(\tilde{v_i})=\sum_{r\neq i} {w_r(i)E_{ir}(\tilde{v_i})}$$
10.  $z_i$, $u_i$(desired speed)energy potentials.$$S_i(\tilde{v_i})=(u_i-\|\tilde{v_i}\|)^2$$ $$D_i(\tilde{v_i})=-\frac{(z_i-p_i)\cdot\tilde{v_i}}{\|z_i-p_i\|\cdot \|\tilde{v_i}\|}$$
11. $s_i$(energy): $$E_i(\tilde{v_i})=I_i(\tilde{v_i})+\lambda_1S_i(\tilde{v_i})+\lambda_2D_i(\tilde{v_i})$$
$\lambda_1$$\lambda_2$$E_i(\tilde{v_i})$$\tilde{v_i}$.()

$c_1$$c_2$(),()
12. $s_1$$s_2$$s_3$$d_{23}$$s_2$$s_3$$S_2$$s_3$$s_1$$s_1$$s_2$$s_3$
![](15214282365054.jpg)
13. $\tilde{v_i^*}$: $$p_i^{t_N}=p_i+(\alpha_N v_i+(1-\alpha_N)\tilde{v_i^*})t_N$$ 
N$\alpha$

15. $t$,11    $t+1$13
